The Electoral College, that is the United States’ system of using electors to cast the actual votes for the president, is an irrational way to elect the United States president. In this essay, I will explain why the Electoral College is an irrational way to elect the president and why it should be abolished.

Firstly, the Electoral College is an irrational way to elect the president because it gives small states too much power. The Electoral College is a system that gives the electors the power to decide who should be the president. Each state has a number of electors equal to the number of its representatives and senators in Congress. If a candidate wins a state’s popular vote, that candidate wins all the electors from that state, regardless of how much the candidate wins by. Therefore, the more populous a state is, the more electors it has, and the more votes it gets. However, the Electoral College allows each state to have equal power, no matter how populous the state is. For example, Wyoming has three electoral votes, while California has 55. Therefore, Wyoming has three times more power than California in the Electoral College. This means that the presidential candidate needs to win the electoral vote of California, a populous state, as well as the electoral votes of many small states, such as Wyoming, in order to win the presidential election. Despite the Electoral College being a system that is supposed to give equal power to each state, it actually gives small states too much power. This is because the presidential candidate needs to win the electoral votes of the small states, as well as the populous states, in order to win the presidential election. Additionally, the Electoral College is an irrational way to elect the president because it allows the president to be elected even though a majority of the people vote against him. The Electoral College gives the electors the power to decide who should be the president. Therefore, if the candidate that wins the popular vote loses the electoral vote, the candidate that wins the electoral vote can become the president. This means that the candidate that wins the popular vote can be elected as the president even though a majority of the people vote against him. For example, in the 2000 presidential election, George W. Bush won the electoral vote, while Al Gore won the popular vote. Therefore, George W. Bush became the 43rd president of the United States, even though a majority of the people voted against him. This shows that the Electoral College allows the president to be elected even though a majority of the people vote against him. This is an irrational way to elect the president because the majority of the people should not be able to be ruled by those who did not win the popular vote. This is because a majority of the people should have the power to rule instead of a minority group of people. Therefore, the Electoral College is an irrational way to elect the president because it gives small states too much power, and allows the president to be elected even though a majority of the people vote against him.

Secondly, the Electoral College is an irrational way to elect the president because it is undemocratic. The Electoral College is a system that gives the electors the power to decide who should be the president. Therefore, the electors decide who should be the president, instead of the people. The people elect the electors, so the electors are not directly elected by the people. This means that the president is elected by a group of people, rather than the people. This is an undemocratic way to elect the president because the president should be elected directly by the people. Extracurricular activities are an integral part of the curriculum in many schools and communities. The benefits of these activities are numerous and include an opportunity for students to learn to work together, to compete against one another, and to work toward a common goal. However, in some schools and communities, the extra curricular activities are not a choice for the students. In my own school, and in my own community, the activities are mandatory, and many students do not benefit from these activities. I believe that by making these activities mandatory, the students are missing out on some of the benefits they would receive if the activities were optional.

The first potential consequence of making extra curricular activities mandatory is the cost of providing the activities. In my school, all students are required to participate in at least one extra curricular activity. This activity is selected for the students by the school and they have no choice in the matter. As a result, the school is responsible for providing uniforms, equipment, and transportation to the activities. This cost is significant for the school and the cost is passed along to the parents. In my own community, the cost of extracurricular activities is minimal because the parents are responsible for providing uniforms and transportation, and the activities are not mandatory. This is because the activities are not a requirement of the school and the school is not responsible for providing them at all.

Another consequence of making extra curricular activities mandatory is the availability of equipment and space. In the school where I work, the extra curricular activities are mandatory, and the school is responsible for providing the equipment and space for them. This equipment is expensive, and the school does not have enough space to provide it for all of the students. In my own community, the activities are not mandatory, and the equipment and space are provided by the parents. Because the activities are not mandatory in my community, the parents are able to provide their own equipment and space for the activities. This is because the parents are not required to provide this equipment and space by the school, and the parents are able to provide it at a cost that is reasonable for them.

A third consequence of making extra curricular activities mandatory is the transportation needed for the students to participate in the activities. In the school where I work, the students are required to take public transportation to and from the activities. This transportation is expensive and the school is responsible for paying for the transportation. In my own community, the activities are not mandatory, and the parents are responsible for providing transportation to the activities. This transportation is provided by the parents, and it is less expensive than the transportation provided by the school. Because the activities are not mandatory, the parents are able to provide the transportation at a cost that is reasonable for them.

In conclusion, the potential consequences of making extra curricular activities mandatory include: the cost of providing the activities, the availability of equipment and space for the activities, and the transportation for the students to participate in the activities. These consequences can be avoided by making the activities optional for the students.

The Facial Action Coding System (FACS) is a system of 46 facial muscle movements that can be associated with specific emotions. It was developed in the 1970’s by two researchers, Paul Ekman and Wallace Friesen, to help understand emotional expressions across cultures. The system has been applied to many different areas, including the health field, to assist in determining a patients’ emotional state (Ekman & Friesen, 1978). A recent application of FACS is in the classroom to help improve student engagement and interest in lessons.

Student engagement and interest in classroom lessons often varies between subjects, teachers, and lessons. By using FACS, teachers can gain an understanding of their students’ emotional state and use this to inform their teaching strategies. For example, if a teacher notices that many of their students are confused by a lesson, they can change their lesson plan to focus on the areas that the students are having difficulty with. The teacher may also change their teaching style to better suit the needs of the students. If a class is full of bored students, the teacher can use a FACS chart to identify the specific facial muscle movements in the “bored” emotion. The teacher can then use this information to change their teaching style to engage the students.

A recent study by Margaritis and colleagues (2015) used FACS to measure student engagement and interest in a college statistics class. The researchers used the FACS to determine the emotional state of the students during an in-class activity. They also used surveys to determine the students’ interest in the activity. The results of the study showed that students who were engaged and interested in the activity had a higher level of positive facial muscle movements than the students who were bored or confused. In addition, students who were engaged and interested in the activity also showed a higher level of positive facial muscle movements than the students who were neutral on the survey. These results support the use of FACS in the classroom to help determine how to best engage and interest students in lessons.

The use of FACS in the classroom can be applied to many different subject areas and grade levels. Teachers can use FACS to determine what emotions their students are experiencing in class and use this information to inform their teaching strategies. By applying FACS to the classroom, teachers can improve student engagement and interest in lessons.
